#Text=Hold a Fork
#Text=Proper table etiquette may vary depending on where you are .
#Text=There are two traditional Western schools of eating with a fork and knife : the European " continental " style , and the American " cut-and-switch " or " zig-zag " style .

column1: #Text=However , the American version may have actually begun several hundred years ago in France .
#Text=In most modern settings , however , it does n't much matter how you hold the fork as long as you 're able to eat efficiently .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Eating " European Style "
#Text=Hold your fork in your left hand .
#Text=Most European eaters keep the knife in their right hand for cutting , and they keep the fork in their left hand for eating .
#Text=In the American style , eaters switch the fork over to their right hand to eat the pieces that they have cut .
#Text=Traditionally , this is the main difference between the European and American forking styles .
#Text=The European style is often considered more efficient because you do n't have to remove the fork from you hand until you are done eating .
#Text=If you 're setting the table for " European-style " eating : make sure to arrange the fork on the left-hand side of the plate , and the knife on the right-hand side .
#Text=Use the fork with the tines facing down .
#Text=This is traditional European etiquette .
#Text=Be aware , however , that many modern
#Text=Europeans not longer pay much heed to which way their tines are facing .
#Text=Hold the handle between your thumb and your middle , ring , and pinky fingers .
#Text=Place your index finger at the end of the handle where it meets the base of the fork tines .
#Text=Let the end of the handle rest in the crease of your palm .
#Text=The lower you place your index finger on the fork handle , the more leverage you 'll have as you eat your food .
#Text=Pick up knife in your right hand .
#Text=Hold it in your hand in the same closed-fist manner that you hold your fork .
#Text=Use it to rake the food onto your fork .
#Text=Fold or push the food onto the tines of your fork with your knife if it is a salad or soft food .
#Text=Use a gentle sawing motion with the knife if you are cutting meat , pizza or a similar food .
#Text=You can actually push more food securely onto your fork with the European method than with the scooping American method .
#Text=Eat your meal .
#Text=Insert the fork into your mouth with the tines still scooping down .
#Text=Do n't turn the fork or put it into your right hand .
#Text=When you are finished , rest your fork and knife parallel on the plate with the tines facing down .
#Text=If you see the plate as a clock face : the tines and blade should be at 10 o'clock , and the handles at 4 o'clock .
#Text=Eating " American Style "
#Text=Cut food with the knife in your right hand and the fork in your left .
#Text=Hold the food in place with the tines of your fork .
#Text=Then , saw with the knife to slice the food item into a bite-sized piece .
#Text=This part is essentially the same as the European method .
#Text=Point the tines down .
#Text=According to traditional " etiquette , " your tines should face down , with your palm wrapped around the end of the handle .
#Text=Extend your index finger to the base of the fork .
#Text=Do n't worry about which way the tines are turned .
#Text=It may be easier to pick up food if you turn your tines upward , like a shovel .
#Text=Most modern Americans do not pay much heed to which way the tines are facing .
#Text=Switch your fork to your right hand to eat .
#Text=After you 've cut the piece of food , place your knife on the edge of the plate .
#Text=Switch your fork to your right hand .
#Text=The end of the fork will rest in the area between your thumb and index finger .
#Text=Use your right hand to bring the food to your mouth , and then switch the fork back over to your left hand so that you can cut another piece with the knife in your right hand .
#Text=Repeat , switching hands each time you take a bite .
#Text=The American method may be more efficient if you cut your entire meal into pieces before you switch the fork to your right hand .
#Text=This way , you wo n't have to keep switching the utensils back and forth .
#Text=Decide which way is more efficient .
#Text=Many modern eaters and etiquette critics claim that the European style is less formal and more efficient than the American method .
#Text=It is less disruptive to the eating process .
#Text=Know that archaic social rules notwithstanding , there is truly no " right " or " wrong " way to hold a fork as long as you can eat your meal .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Set your napkin in your lap before you pick up your utensil .
#Text=European-style eating may take some practice if you 're used to the American method .
#Text=However , it may be easier and more efficient to eat your meal in this fashion .
